p: Several solvents have been used for the extraction of lignans for analytical purposes. Pure methanol [ 88], mixtures of methanol and chloroform [ 121, 126] (which do not extract glycosides), a mixture of ethanol with water [ 58], and a mixture of ethanol with acetate buffer [ 104] have been used. Other extraction solvents used in the past included heptane or hexane with isopropanol in a 1:3 ratio [ 54, 101], and acetone/water [ 147, 184]. Extraction with 80% ethanol without previous defatting [ 58] is the standard protocol today (e.g., [ 59, 60, 61]). 80% methanol is also occasionally used [ 94, 185]. Apart from aglycons and monoglucosides, 80% ethanol (and likely 80% methanol) extracts di-glucosides. Tri-glucosides were successfully extracted into 80% ethanol by some authors [ 52, 76, 100] while other found tri-glucosides in the insoluble residues after extracting seeds with 80% ethanol [ 53]. 70% acetone is an interesting alternative to 80% ethanol because it is suitable for the extraction of all lignans [ 186] as well as their conjugates [ 147].
